awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement:  Challenging Assumptions of Dental Senescence Using a Primate Framework
awd_abstract_narration:
Extensive tooth wear may ablate functional features of the teeth, resulting in the end of the dentition's capacity to effectively break down food items (i.e., dental senescence). Such a loss of function is presumed to impede access to foods, resulting in reduced health status, reproductive success, and ability to survive. Nevertheless, how and at what point of wear teeth reach a senescent state is not yet well understood, nor is the extent to which dental senescence may affect individual health, nutrition and behavior. Natural selection should produce teeth which maintain the ability to fracture foods despite wear, and which only cease to function with severe wear. Individuals may compensate for dental impairment through behavioral mechanisms, or may be buffered against the impacts of wear by individual traits such as sex and/or social rank.

This study, by doctoral student James Millette (University of Colorado), under supervision of Dr. Michelle Sauther, combines Geographic Information Systems-based dental topographic analysis of tooth form with individual behavioral-ecology, health and nutritional data to examine relationships between worn tooth morphology, food processing ability and behavior for ring-tailed lemurs (Lemur catta) of the Beza Mahafaly Special Reserve, Madagascar. This population demonstrates well-documented, varying levels of tooth wear and frequent tooth loss due to tamarind fruit consumption.

The research will: 1) determine what level of dental wear is associated with reduced health and nutrition, 2) assess if behavioral mechanisms can buffer individuals against the effects of dental wear, and 3) examine whether individual traits such as rank and sex may impact such patterns. It also will provide valuable contextual information towards improved use of dental topographic analysis for assessing worn tooth functionality and its relation to behavior and nutrition within the primate fossil record.  The conduct of the research will be complemented by enhancing international research collaborations, training of Malagasy students and educational outreach to local communities, and enhanced conservation of endangered habitats.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO

por.por_cntn:
Among nonhuman primates teeth are used for the initial processing of foods and their subsequent physical breakdown through mastication. Efficient mastication also contributes to the animal’s ability to digest and subsequently obtain energy and nutrients from food. While natural selection should produce teeth which function across an animal’s lifespan, significant tooth wear and/or loss may result in an inability to effectively masticate food items (e.g., dental senescence). Such impairment may negatively impact the individual’s health, survival and reproduction, and may also result changes to behavior. However, few data examining the impacts of dental impairment on such variables are available for wild primates. Likewise, little is known about the process by which teeth reach a senescent state or maintain their function through wear prior to the onset of senescence.

This study examines the impact of dental impairment on health, behavior, ecology and nutrition within a population of wild ring-tailed lemurs from the Beza Mahafaly Special Reserve, Madagascar (BMSR). These primates show exceptionally high rates of tooth wear and loss due to consumption of the very hard and tough fruit of Tamarindus indica. Field observations were conducted from June 2012 - March 2013 for 36 individuals of known tooth wear and loss status, during which activity and food processing data were recorded. Additionally, approximately 1300 fecal samples were collected for nutritional analyses. Visual indicators of health, coat and body condition were also recorded for each subject twice-monthly. Following return from the field, dental topographic analyses, which model tooth wear in three dimensions, were conducted at the University of Arkansas on dental casts from each subject. Topographic data were then assessed in relation to behavioral measures collected at BMSR. Fecal nutritional assays were also conducted at the University of Colorado, with a variety of nutrients (e.g., fiber, protein, ash, etc.) being assessed relative to individual dental impairment status.

Our fecal nutritional data indicate lemurs with dental impairment digest food items less efficiently in comparison to individuals without impairment, resulting in greater amounts of nutrients within their feces. Such impacts are most evident during the resource-depleted dry season, suggesting that these individuals face significant challenges accessing foods during this time. Feeding data also indicate that individuals with dental impairment take longer to consume challenging foods, particularly Tamarindus indica fruit, a key dry season resource at BMSR. Interestingly, individuals with extensive tooth loss were observed to process tamarind fruit using the hands to remove this food’s mechanically-challenging outer shell, a behavior rarely employed by those without loss. This suggests these animals compensate behaviorally against the impacts of dental impairment, potentially contributing to their continued health and survival. Additionally, dentally impaired lemurs have greater amounts of silicates within their feces. Silicates are a major source of dental wear among mammals, and may be contributing to impairment seen at BMSR in addition to that due to tamarind fruit consumption.

Results from this study indicate that dental impairment negatively impacts the individual’s ability to process and utilize food resources. Our data also suggest that individuals may, however, alter their behaviors to compensate against dental impairment. These findings are of particular interest for interpreting the fossil record. While fossil primates with tooth wear are commonly found, few comparative data with which to adequately reconstruct their lives and behavior are available from living primates with tooth wear or loss. That dental impairment is associated with reduced nutrient uptake...
